Name: Cholanaickan Tribal Settlement
Historical/Cultural Background: Home to one of India's most isolated tribes who lived in caves until recently. They are master honey gatherers and forest knowledge experts.
Uniqueness Factor: One of the last hunter-gatherer communities in South India with extensive knowledge of medicinal plants. Their language is unique and not written down.
Things to Do: Guided visits to forest periphery with tribal guides; learning about honey collection; medicinal plant walks; cultural exchange programs through government-sanctioned tribal welfare initiatives.
How to Get There: 60 km from Nilambur, Kerala. Nearest airport is Kozhikode; nearest railway station is Nilambur Road.
Accessibility Info: Not suitable for elderly or wheelchair users; visits only with official permission and guides; not for independent travelers.
Accommodation Options: No accommodations in tribal areas; stay in Nilambur or nearby areas
Local Cuisine Specialties: Traditional tribal food includes tubers, wild honey, bamboo rice, and foraged greens
Cultural Events: No public festivals; occasional cultural programs organized by Tribal Department

Name: Dong Village
Historical/Cultural Background: Easternmost village in India where the sun rises first in the country. Located near the tri-junction of India, China, and Myanmar borders.
Uniqueness Factor: First place in India to receive sunlight each morning (around 5:30 AM). Traditional Meyor tribe settlement with unique cultural practices influenced by Tibetan Buddhism.
Things to Do: Experience India's earliest sunrise; village walks; photography; bird watching; learning about Meyor culture; trekking along nearby hills; visit to Dong Monastery.
How to Get There: 50 km from Walong. Nearest airport is Dibrugarh (connection via road/helicopter); permits required for all visitors.
Accessibility Info: Challenging for elderly and not wheelchair accessible; inner line permits required; guided tours essential.
Accommodation Options: Basic homestays in the village; government inspection bungalow with prior booking
Local Cuisine Specialties: Thukpa; momos; local rice preparations; fermented bamboo shoot dishes; butter tea
Cultural Events: Buddhist festivals following Tibetan calendar; Losar celebrations

Name: Ziro Valley
Historical/Cultural Background: Home to the Apatani tribe known for their unique face tattoos and nose plugs. UNESCO World Heritage Site contender.
Uniqueness Factor: One of India's few rice-cum-fish cultivation systems. The valley has distinctive bamboo and pine forests with picturesque villages.
Things to Do: Trekking in the valley floor; attending Ziro Music Festival (September); photography of paddy fields; homestay with Apatani tribe; exploring Talley Valley Wildlife Sanctuary.
How to Get There: Nearest airport is Jorhat (Assam) 4 hours away. Helicopter service from Naharlagun to Ziro. Train to Naharlagun then taxi to Ziro.
Accessibility Info: Moderate difficulty for elderly; not wheelchair accessible; safe for solo travelers with basic precautions.
Accommodation Options: Homestays in traditional Apatani houses; Ziro Valley Resort; few guest houses in Old Ziro and New Ziro
Local Cuisine Specialties: Bamboo shoots with pork; fermented rice beer (apong); smoked meat dishes; fish from paddy fields
Cultural Events: Ziro Music Festival (September); Myoko Festival (March); Dree Festival (July)

Name: Majuli Island
Historical/Cultural Background: World's largest river island on the Brahmaputra. Center of Assamese neo-Vaishnavite culture with ancient monasteries (satras) dating back to the 15th century.
Uniqueness Factor: Unique tradition of mask-making at Samaguri Satra. The island is gradually eroding due to the Brahmaputra river and may disappear in coming decades.
Things to Do: Visit ancient satras (monasteries); watch mask-making process; bicycle around the island; boat rides on the Brahmaputra; bird watching during winter; cultural performances at satras.
How to Get There: Ferry from Nimati Ghat (Jorhat) to Kamalabari Ghat. Nearest airport is Jorhat; nearest railway station is Jorhat.
Accessibility Info: Limited accessibility for disabled visitors; senior-friendly with assistance; safe for solo travelers.
Accommodation Options: La Maison de Ananda; Me:Po Okum; Deka Chang; numerous homestays
Local Cuisine Specialties: Assamese thalis with fresh fish; poitabhat (fermented rice); duck meat with ash gourd
Cultural Events: Raas Leela (November); Paal Naam performances at satras; Ali-Ai-Ligang (February)

Name: Champaner-Pavagadh Archaeological Park
Historical/Cultural Background: UNESCO World Heritage Site with structures dating from the 8th to 14th centuries. Ancient Hindu and Jain temples along with Islamic monuments.
Uniqueness Factor: Only complete unchanged pre-Mughal Islamic city in India. Contains ruins from multiple periods showcasing evolution of architectural styles over 600 years.
Things to Do: Explore Jami Masjid; hike to Pavagadh Hill and Kalika Mata Temple; visit the step wells; photography of ancient structures; archeological explorations of lesser-known ruins.
How to Get There: 57 km from Vadodara. Nearest airport and railway station is Vadodara.
Accessibility Info: Moderately accessible for elderly; partial wheelchair access in main monuments; solo travel friendly.
Accommodation Options: Limited options near the site. Best to stay in Vadodara and make a day trip.
Local Cuisine Specialties: Gujarati thali; dhokla; khandvi; dal dhokli available in nearby small eateries
Cultural Events: Navratri celebrations at Kalika Mata Temple (September/October)

Name: Unakoti
Historical/Cultural Background: Rock-cut sculptures and stone images from 7th-9th centuries depicting Lord Shiva and other Hindu deities. The name means 'one less than a crore' in Bengali.
Uniqueness Factor: Features massive 30-foot high bas-relief carvings on a hillside. Legend says these are divine artisans turned to stone after failing to create a crore sculptures in one night.
Things to Do: Explore the massive rock carvings; photography; meditation in the serene environment; hiking around the forested area; visit nearby waterfalls.
How to Get There: 178 km from Agartala. Nearest railhead is Kumarghat (20 km). Nearest airport is Agartala.
Accessibility Info: Challenging for elderly and wheelchair users due to hillside location and steps; reasonable for solo travelers.
Accommodation Options: Limited accommodations in Kailashahar (12 km away); better options in Agartala
Local Cuisine Specialties: Traditional Tripuri cuisine; bamboo shoot preparations; berma (fermented fish); chuak (rice beer)
Cultural Events: Ashokastami Festival (April) when thousands of pilgrims visit

Name: Hemis National Park
Historical/Cultural Background: Largest national park in South Asia and home to the endangered snow leopard. Established in 1981 but the area has ancient Buddhist connections.
Uniqueness Factor: One of the best places in the world to spot the elusive snow leopard. Also houses ancient monasteries amid stunning high-altitude Himalayan landscapes.
Things to Do: Wildlife spotting (snow leopards from Jan-Mar); trekking; visit to Hemis Monastery; photography; homestay in traditional Ladakhi houses in Rumbak village.
How to Get There: 40 km from Leh. Nearest airport is Leh. Entry through organized tours only with permits.
Accessibility Info: Not suitable for elderly or wheelchair users; moderate to difficult trekking; experienced solo travelers only with guides.
Best Time to Visit: Winter (Jan-Mar) for snow leopards; summer (May-Sep) for trekking and general exploration
Accommodation Options: Homestays in Rumbak village; camping during treks; no luxury accommodations inside the park
Local Cuisine Specialties: Thukpa; skyu; chhutagi; butter tea; chang (barley beer)

Name: Chettinad
Historical/Cultural Background: Historical region known for the palatial houses of the wealthy Nattukottai Chettiar merchant community who traded across Southeast Asia.
Uniqueness Factor: Mansions built with materials from around the world including Italian marble, Japanese tiles, and Burmese teak. Unique architectural style blending Western and Eastern influences.
Things to Do: Mansion tours in Karaikudi; antique shopping; Chettinad cuisine experiences; photography of architectural details; tile-making workshops; temple visits.
How to Get There: Nearest airport is Madurai (90 km); nearest railway station is Karaikudi.
Accessibility Info: Suitable for elderly with assistance; limited wheelchair accessibility in old mansions; safe for solo travelers.
Accommodation Options: The Bangala; Visalam; Chidambara Vilas; Chettinadu Mansion - all heritage hotels converted from original mansions
Local Cuisine Specialties: Chettinad chicken/mutton; Kavuni arisi (black rice pudding); paniyaram; vegetable kothu; kuzhi paniyaram
Cultural Events: Kothaipongal (January); local temple festivals throughout year

Name: Dzukou Valley
Historical/Cultural Background: Valley on the border of Nagaland and Manipur at an altitude of 2450m. Traditional territory of the Angami Naga tribe.
Uniqueness Factor: Famous for its seasonal burst of lilies and rare Dzukou lily found nowhere else in the world. Features uniquely sculpted valleys and rolling hills with dwarf bamboo patches.
Things to Do: Trekking; camping; photography especially during lily season (May-September); botanizing; star gazing; experiencing Naga culture in nearby villages.
How to Get There: Trek starts from Viswema or Zakhama village. Nearest airport and railway station is Dimapur (100 km from Kohima).
Accessibility Info: Challenging for elderly and not wheelchair accessible; experienced trekkers recommended; guided tours advisable for solo travelers.
Best Time to Visit: May-September for lilies; October-April for clear views
Accommodation Options: Basic accommodations at rest house in the valley; camping; better options in Kohima
Local Cuisine Specialties: Smoked pork with bamboo shoot; axone (fermented soybean); zutho (rice beer); fish cooked in bamboo
Cultural Events: Hornbill Festival (December) in nearby Kohima; Sekrenyi Festival (February)

Name: Gurez Valley
Historical/Cultural Background: Remote valley near the Line of Control that was closed to tourists until recently. Inhabited by the Dard-Shin tribe who have preserved their unique culture.
Uniqueness Factor: One of the few places where the ancient Shina language is still spoken. Spectacular views of snow-capped Habba Khatoon peak and the Kishanganga River.
Things to Do: Trout fishing in Kishanganga River; trekking to Tulail Valley; visiting ancient Habba Khatoon tower; photography; cultural exploration of Dard-Shin traditions; homestays.
How to Get There: 123 km from Srinagar. Nearest airport is Srinagar. Road access only during summer months (May-October).
Accessibility Info: Not suitable for elderly or wheelchair users; requires security clearances as it's near LOC; solo travel possible but challenging.
Accommodation Options: J&K Tourism guest house; homestays in Dawar village; camping options
Local Cuisine Specialties: Gurez trout preparations; rajma-chawal; noon chai (salt tea); traditional Dard-Shin dishes
Cultural Events: Local folk dance performances in summer; Peer Baba festival at Habba Khatoon shrine

Name: Mechuka Valley
Historical/Cultural Background: A remote valley near the Indo-Tibet border, home to the Memba tribe and a 400-year-old Buddhist monastery.
Uniqueness Factor: Pristine landscapes, wooden houses, and a unique blend of Buddhist and tribal cultures.
Things to Do: Trekking, monastery visits, river rafting, explore local villages.
How to Get There: Nearest airport is Dibrugarh (Assam), then 7-8 hr drive. Permits required.
Accessibility Info: Not wheelchair accessible; basic facilities only.
Accommodation Options: Homestays and guesthouses in Mechuka town.

Name: Haflong
Historical/Cultural Background: Assam's only hill station, known for its scenic beauty, Dimasa culture, and Haflong Lake.
Uniqueness Factor: Rolling hills, tribal villages, and orchid gardens.
Things to Do: Boating on Haflong Lake, trekking, visiting Jatinga (famous for bird phenomenon).
How to Get There: Nearest railhead is Haflong Hill; Silchar airport 100 km away.
Accessibility Info: Good for all ages; some hilly terrain.
Local Cuisine Specialties: Sticky rice, bamboo shoot dishes, fish curry.

Name: Tawang Monastery
Historical/Cultural Background: Largest monastery in India, founded in the 17th century. Center of Mahayana Buddhism in the region.
Uniqueness Factor: Spectacular hilltop setting, rich monastic traditions.
Things to Do: Attend morning prayers, explore museum, trek to nearby lakes.
How to Get There: Nearest airport is Tezpur, then 12 hr drive; permits required.
Accessibility Info: Not wheelchair accessible; high altitude.

Name: Sandakphu
Historical/Cultural Background: Highest peak in West Bengal, part of Singalila Ridge, offering panoramic views of four of the world's five highest peaks.
Uniqueness Factor: Only place in India to see Everest, Kanchenjunga, Lhotse, and Makalu together.
Things to Do: Trekking, rhododendron watching, birding.
How to Get There: Trek from Manebhanjan (near Darjeeling); nearest airport is Bagdogra.
Accessibility Info: Not suitable for elderly or wheelchair users.

Name: Chopta
Historical/Cultural Background: Known as the 'Mini Switzerland of India', Chopta is the base for the Tungnath trek, the highest Shiva temple.
Uniqueness Factor: Alpine meadows, rhododendron forests, and Himalayan views.
Things to Do: Trekking to Tungnath and Chandrashila, camping, bird watching.
How to Get There: Drive from Rishikesh/Haridwar (200 km); nearest railhead is Haridwar.
Accessibility Info: Basic guesthouses, some tented camps.

Name: Chakrata
Historical/Cultural Background: A cantonment town established by the British, surrounded by deodar forests.
Uniqueness Factor: Secluded hill station with ancient caves and waterfalls.
Things to Do: Visit Tiger Falls, Deoban, Budher Caves, trekking.
How to Get There: 100 km from Dehradun; nearest airport is Jolly Grant.
Accessibility Info: Good for families; some sites require trekking.

Name: Lonar Crater
Historical/Cultural Background: A 52,000-year-old meteorite crater lake, surrounded by ancient temples.
Uniqueness Factor: Only hyper-velocity impact crater in basaltic rock on Earth.
Things to Do: Visit Daitya Sudan temple, birdwatching, nature walks.
How to Get There: 150 km from Aurangabad; nearest railhead is Jalna.
Accessibility Info: Some uneven terrain; basic facilities.

Name: Kaas Plateau
Historical/Cultural Background: UNESCO World Natural Heritage Site, known as the 'Valley of Flowers of Maharashtra'.
Uniqueness Factor: Carpet of wildflowers blooms after monsoon.
Things to Do: Photography, nature walks, visit nearby Vajrai Waterfall.
How to Get There: 25 km from Satara; nearest airport is Pune.
Accessibility Info: Not suitable for wheelchair users; short walks.

Name: Chitrakote Falls
Historical/Cultural Background: India's widest waterfall, called the 'Niagara of India', on the Indravati River.
Uniqueness Factor: Spectacular horseshoe-shaped falls in dense forest.
Things to Do: Boat rides, photography, visit nearby tribal villages.
How to Get There: 40 km from Jagdalpur; nearest airport is Raipur.
Accessibility Info: Some steps; not wheelchair accessible.
Local Cuisine Specialties: Chana sagra, fara, tribal mahua liquor.

Name: Tso Moriri
Historical/Cultural Background: High-altitude lake at 4,522 m, less visited than Pangong, in Changthang plateau.
Uniqueness Factor: Pristine blue lake, migratory birds, Changpa nomads.
Things to Do: Photography, bird watching, visit Korzok Monastery.
How to Get There: 220 km from Leh; self-drive or taxi; permits required.
Accessibility Info: High altitude; not for elderly or those with health issues.

Name: Dholavira
Historical/Cultural Background: One of the five largest Harappan sites in the world, located in the Rann of Kutch.
Uniqueness Factor: Ancient city ruins with sophisticated water management.
Things to Do: Explore archaeological site, fossil park, sunset at White Rann.
How to Get There: 220 km from Bhuj; nearest airport is Bhuj.
Accessibility Info: Some uneven terrain; basic facilities.

Name: Sualkuchi
Historical/Cultural Background: Known as the 'Manchester of Assam', this village is famed for its centuries-old silk weaving tradition.
Uniqueness Factor: Traditional looms in every house, Muga and Eri silk production.
Things to Do: Weaving workshops, buy handloom sarees, interact with artisans.
How to Get There: 35 km from Guwahati; local buses and taxis available.
Accessibility Info: Good for all ages; village roads.

Name: Khonoma
Historical/Cultural Background: India's first green village, famous for Angami tribe's conservation efforts and terraced fields.
Uniqueness Factor: Community-run eco-tourism, unique forest management.
Things to Do: Village walks, birdwatching, learn about Angami customs.
How to Get There: 20 km from Kohima; taxis and shared jeeps available.
Accessibility Info: Some hilly paths; basic facilities.
Local Cuisine Specialties: Smoked pork, sticky rice, bamboo shoot curry.

Name: Mawlynnong
Historical/Cultural Background: Awarded 'Asia's Cleanest Village', famous for living root bridges and eco-friendly practices.
Uniqueness Factor: Man-made root bridges, spotless streets, matrilineal Khasi culture.
Things to Do: Walk on root bridges, village tour, visit Sky View platform.
How to Get There: 80 km from Shillong; taxis and shared vehicles.
Accessibility Info: Suitable for all ages; some walking.

Name: Ziro Valley
Historical/Cultural Background: UNESCO World Heritage contender, home to Apatani tribe and their unique paddy-cum-fish farming.
Uniqueness Factor: Distinctive bamboo and pine forests, Apatani culture.
Things to Do: Trekking, homestays, Ziro Music Festival.
How to Get There: Nearest airport is Jorhat (Assam), then road to Ziro.
Accessibility Info: Moderate difficulty for elderly; not wheelchair accessible.
Local Cuisine Specialties: Bamboo shoots with pork, apong (rice beer).

Name: Keibul Lamjao National Park
Historical/Cultural Background: World's only floating national park, home to endangered Sangai deer.
Uniqueness Factor: Unique phumdi (floating biomass) ecosystem.
Things to Do: Boat rides, wildlife spotting, photography.
How to Get There: 53 km from Imphal; taxis and buses available.
Accessibility Info: Some boardwalks; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Phugtal Monastery
Historical/Cultural Background: A remote cave monastery built into a cliff face, accessible only by foot.
Uniqueness Factor: Spectacular architecture, centuries-old Buddhist traditions.
Things to Do: Trek to monastery, interact with monks, meditation.
How to Get There: Trek from Padum (Zanskar Valley); no motorable road.
Accessibility Info: Difficult trek; not accessible for elderly.

Name: Bhedaghat
Historical/Cultural Background: Famed for marble rocks rising 100 ft above the Narmada River.
Uniqueness Factor: Dramatic white cliffs, Dhuandhar Falls, boat rides under moonlight.
Things to Do: Boat ride, cable car, visit Chausath Yogini Temple.
How to Get There: 23 km from Jabalpur; taxis and buses available.
Accessibility Info: Some steps; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Gandikota
Historical/Cultural Background: Known as the 'Grand Canyon of India', with a 13th-century fort overlooking a deep gorge.
Uniqueness Factor: Spectacular red sandstone cliffs on the Pennar River.
Things to Do: Explore Gandikota Fort, kayaking, camping, photography.
How to Get There: 77 km from Kadapa; nearest railhead is Jammalamadugu.
Accessibility Info: Some rough terrain; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Lepakshi
Historical/Cultural Background: 16th-century temple complex with hanging pillar and giant Nandi statue.
Uniqueness Factor: Vijayanagara architecture, legendary murals.
Things to Do: Explore temple, photography, learn about legends.
How to Get There: 120 km from Bengaluru; buses and taxis available.
Accessibility Info: Temple has steps; partial wheelchair access.

Name: Bhimbetka Rock Shelters
Historical/Cultural Background: UNESCO World Heritage Site with prehistoric cave paintings dating back 30,000 years.
Uniqueness Factor: Ancient art, natural rock formations.
Things to Do: Guided tours, photography, nature walks.
How to Get There: 45 km from Bhopal; taxis and buses available.
Accessibility Info: Some uneven terrain; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Chilika Lake
Historical/Cultural Background: Asia's largest brackish water lagoon, winter home to millions of migratory birds.
Uniqueness Factor: Irrawaddy dolphins, birdwatching, fishing villages.
Things to Do: Boat rides, birdwatching, visit Kalijai Island.
How to Get There: Nearest railhead is Balugaon; 120 km from Bhubaneswar.
Accessibility Info: Boat rides accessible; some uneven terrain.

Name: Dzukou Valley
Historical/Cultural Background: Valley on Nagaland-Manipur border, home to rare Dzukou lily.
Uniqueness Factor: Rolling hills, seasonal wildflowers, bamboo groves.
Things to Do: Trekking, camping, photography.
How to Get There: Trek from Viswema or Zakhama; nearest airport is Dimapur.
Accessibility Info: Tough trek; not for elderly or wheelchair users.

Name: Bhimbetka Rock Shelters
Historical/Cultural Background: UNESCO World Heritage Site with prehistoric cave paintings dating back 30,000 years.
Uniqueness Factor: Ancient art, natural rock formations.
Things to Do: Guided tours, photography, nature walks.
How to Get There: 45 km from Bhopal; taxis and buses available.
Accessibility Info: Some uneven terrain; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Chettinad
Historical/Cultural Background: Region of palatial mansions and unique Chettiar cuisine.
Uniqueness Factor: Distinctive architecture, antique markets.
Things to Do: Mansion tours, food trails, tile workshops.
How to Get There: Nearest airport is Madurai; 90 km by road.
Accessibility Info: Most mansions have steps; some accessible rooms.

Name: Araku Valley
Historical/Cultural Background: Scenic valley in the Eastern Ghats, home to tribal communities and coffee plantations.
Uniqueness Factor: Waterfalls, caves, tribal culture.
Things to Do: Train journey from Vizag, coffee museum, Borra Caves.
How to Get There: 120 km from Visakhapatnam; train or road.
Accessibility Info: Some hilly terrain; basic facilities.

Name: Haflong
Historical/Cultural Background: Assam's only hill station, known for its scenic beauty, Dimasa culture, and Haflong Lake.
Uniqueness Factor: Rolling hills, tribal villages, and orchid gardens.
Things to Do: Boating on Haflong Lake, trekking, visiting Jatinga (famous for bird phenomenon).
How to Get There: Nearest railhead is Haflong Hill; Silchar airport 100 km away.
Accessibility Info: Good for all ages; some hilly terrain.
Local Cuisine Specialties: Sticky rice, bamboo shoot dishes, fish curry.

Name: Gurez Valley
Historical/Cultural Background: Remote valley near the Line of Control, home to Dard-Shin tribe and Habba Khatoon peak.
Uniqueness Factor: Ancient Shina language, pristine river views.
Things to Do: Trekking, trout fishing, cultural immersion.
How to Get There: 123 km from Srinagar; road open May-October.
Accessibility Info: Not wheelchair accessible; security checks.

Name: Dudhsagar Falls
Historical/Cultural Background: One of India's tallest waterfalls, on the Mandovi River in the Western Ghats.
Uniqueness Factor: Spectacular four-tiered waterfall, accessible by train or trek.
Things to Do: Trekking, swimming, photography.
How to Get There: 60 km from Panaji; train to Castle Rock or trek from Kulem.
Accessibility Info: Trek is challenging; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Chandipur Beach
Historical/Cultural Background: Famous for the 'vanishing sea'-the water recedes up to 5 km during low tide.
Uniqueness Factor: Unique tidal phenomenon, horseshoe crab sightings.
Things to Do: Beach walks, seafood, shell collecting.
How to Get There: 16 km from Balasore; nearest railhead is Balasore.
Accessibility Info: Beach accessible; some sandy areas.

Name: St. Mary's Islands
Historical/Cultural Background: Cluster of four small islands with unique hexagonal basaltic rock formations.
Uniqueness Factor: Columnar lava formations, white sand beaches.
Things to Do: Ferry ride, photography, shell collecting.
How to Get There: Ferry from Malpe (Udupi); nearest airport is Mangalore.
Accessibility Info: Ferry access only; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Dhanushkodi
Historical/Cultural Background: Abandoned town at the tip of Rameswaram island, destroyed in 1964 cyclone.
Uniqueness Factor: Ghost town, mythological Ramayana connection.
Things to Do: Visit ruins, Adam's Bridge viewpoint, birdwatching.
How to Get There: 20 km from Rameswaram; local jeeps only.
Accessibility Info: Sandy terrain; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Mawphlang Sacred Grove
Historical/Cultural Background: Ancient forest protected by Khasi tribes for centuries, rich in biodiversity and folklore.
Uniqueness Factor: No tree or stone can be removed; unique flora.
Things to Do: Guided forest walks, learn Khasi rituals.
How to Get There: 25 km from Shillong; taxis available.
Accessibility Info: Forest trails; not wheelchair accessible.

Name: Krem Liat Prah
Historical/Cultural Background: India's longest natural cave system, over 30 km explored.
Uniqueness Factor: Stunning stalactites, underground rivers.
Things to Do: Caving (with guides), photography.
How to Get There: Near Nongjri village, 60 km from Shillong.
Accessibility Info: Physically demanding; not for elderly or those with claustrophobia.

Name: Auli
Historical/Cultural Background: High-altitude ski resort with panoramic views of Nanda Devi and other peaks.
Uniqueness Factor: Best ski slopes in India, cable car rides.
Things to Do: Skiing, trekking, chair lift, camping.
How to Get There: 16 km from Joshimath; cable car from Joshimath.
Accessibility Info: Skiing requires fitness; cable car accessible.
